reviews.review_msg: Such an awesome prof! Dr. Baxter is the perfect mix of knowledgeable and easy-going. She remembers what it was like to be a student in university and keeps the level of difficulty appropriate. Only one midterm, mini assignments, and a final paper. Not hard at all! I recommend taking this class with Dr. B!

She has a major problem when it comes to clear speech and clarity of her sentences. She always stops her sentences mid-way and then begins with a new topic. She messed up the syllabus in terms of grading for our paper and final, which ultimately made it almost impossible to get a decent mark. And her exams are only on the details of the text, notle

Great class and Prof. Definitely makes you work hard, but it's worth it because you will learn a lot! Provides very helpful handouts. High expectations, but they are all very clear and grading is transparent and fair.

If you like to work hard, engage in lively class discussions, and learn exciting new things, Lorraine is for you.  If you've been getting through school on cruise control, you'll be in for a shock because she has very high standards and expectations.  Makes a great effort to help students understand material, and is very approachable and accessible

He clearly cares about the issues he teaches and invests a ton of time and effort into his students. The content was comprehensive yet digestible. He has a great sense of humour and made the class fun, but had clear expectations. Definitely important to participate. Would take any of his classes.

HSCI449.This guy does not know what communication is. He NEVER responds to emails even when you send follow-up emails. He says "Don't worry about it, it's very easy and as long as you write something within the rubric, you'll get an A". Well, that's a LIE! HARD MARKER! and his rubric are not clear at all. He's a nice person, but SHITTY PROF! AVOID!

I thought the class was really easy... the concepts are super important and relevant if you want to remain in the health field. Just go in with an open mind and a willingness to learn. I would read the readings the night before and I got 5/5 on every quiz. He would ask questions like "what does intersectionality mean," - super easy.

Vishal is a nice person, but not an appropriate educator. He confuses almost everything; lectures, assignments, quizzes, exams. He over complicates things! In addition to that, there is no point in asking him questions because the answer will be over the top complicated. I would avoid taking classes with him. Just don't do it. Seriously.
The course itself is challenging, but Vishal is very helpful during office hour if you have any issue. Vishal is a good listener, he very patient.

Super good prof, however to do good in this class you have to go in depth in his readings. I tried studying his notes for his midterm and only got a 70%, but I ended up with an A-. He's really helpful if you go to him after class or during break and the quizzes are great exam prep. I hope to take another course with him in the future

If kindness made an instructor good at their job, then Dr. Jain would be all set. Unfortunately that's not the case. This person cannot facilitate meaningful class discussion, and generally may have the qualifications to teach this course but in now way has the expertise. Not great with accountability, regardless of how friendly he tries to be.

Vishal is super approachable & understanding. He tries to make dry topics interesting. He assigns a lot of readings which you get quizzed on some weeks but generally the quizzes are fair. The midterm was a bit difficult and the reviews for it were misleading. Gives you lots of chances to redeem. Over all he's a good prof and I would take him again!

The prof tries hard to be nice in a way to make us feel like the class is okay. BUT ITS NOT! readings are hard to understand and complicated in terms of its concepts. The contexts covered in this class( which are pretty much already covered in other HSCI classes) are demonstrated in a very complex way which is hard to be understood by human beings.

Complex readings without the explanation of what the concepts are beforehand. Started off the term really well by having everything laid out nicely, however as the semester progressed, lectures started getting dry and boring. Tough grader.

Requires students to read complex papers and quizzes the students on topics covered with complex questions in readings before he discusses and explain concepts to students in class. Refuses to posts lecture slides before class and doesn't tell students what will and won't be on edited version of lecture slides.

Maya is a very lovely professor. It is an effort-based course. The assignments were time-consuming, but there were no midterms, quizzes, or final exams. It's amazing. Attendance matters, as she gives questions to write during the lecture for the participation grade. TAs are great as well.

I loved Maya's class; she is so positive and understanding! Her teaching method is structured so that students can easily grasp the knowledge. The class provides a safe environment where she encourages students to express their thoughts. Additionally, there is a group project that will take the entire term to complete.
Freest A+ in my life, maya is the gooaaaaaatttt

She is very passionate about the material and truly cares about how you are doing in life and in class. There are a few participation activities as well as 4 assignments- 3 of which are group assignments. Great person and professor, however, she does not provide clear assignment instructions and then the TAs expect you to know what to do.

Maya is a great lecturer and she is very passionate about the material. Class was transformed to relate to the current COVID-19 situation. Graded on discussions + 3 assignments which were fun and interesting! Gained valuable life lessons and insightful information from this class. TAs are amazing and gave extensions on all our assignments. Take it!

Maya is an absolutely wonderful person and extremely caring. Not absolutely mandatory to attend classes, but it is nice to as she explains the slides in depth and describes useful information that helps you answer questions on exams. Your grade really depends on the TA like always, but if there's an issue, send an email. They are happy to go over.

Maya is really nice. It's really easy to do well in this course as long as you put in the work. Do the readings, study the lectures, and put in the effort for the TBL assignments. The assignments are straightforward and easy to write because they are really informal. Easy course, though a lot of the content wasn't new to me and many students.

Maya's honestly one of the most caring professors i've ever had. She's very helpful and her exams are very straightforward. memorize the review slides she makes, and you'll ace the midterm and final. the quizzes are easy if you read the articles.

This was her first semester at SFU so i wasn't sure what to expect. She is the sweetest prof and really cares about her students. She is a really easy marker, only down side is the high class average . The midterms and projects are easy , would highly recommend her !
Really great prof, clearly passionate. No more work than you would expect out of a class, probably even less than most upper divisions. This is the only class that I honestly recommend to my peers.

This was one of my worst SFU experiences. Lectures were impressively unorganized and uninspiring. If not for the weekly in-class group work I would've never attended. A disappoint since the topics covered in this course genuinely interest me. I don't appreciate having my time wasted, especially in upper division courses. I gained nothing from this.

Viviane was an ok prof. She was really nice, but she started her first lecture by essentially saying she was a PhD student, so if we had questions make sure they weren't questions answered somewhere else b/c she doesn't have time. Kind of disorganized, pretty much assigned readings and videos and didn't teach much. Grading was not clear.

A queen. Class is labour-based so participation is required, but she gives flexibility and allows 2 absences per semester. Make sure to do all the assignments on time (which are not hard) and you will get an A+. Having a good group for the group project might also be helpful.

Professor Berry is by far the best HSCI prof at SFU. She really cares about her students and is passionate about what she teaches. Dr.Berry is very approachable and easy to have conversations with. This course is labour-based so get ready to put in the work and learn discipline and you will do great!!! More profs need to be like Dr.Berry

Dr. Nicole Berry was a great professor! She liked our class as my peers and I were always engaging in class discussions. This class isn't your standard based grading; rather, it is through completion/effort. If you're a hard worker like me and do not procrastinate, you'll LOVE this class. If you procrastinate, this class will be difficult for you.

missing 3 classes resulted in my grade dropping to a C. The instructor is rigid, unwilling to consider alternatives or offer assistance, and lacks flexibility. The grading system penalizes for missed work and is very unfair. the optional assignment support was the only reason I didn't fail the class due to the instructor's flawed grading system.

The new grading system worked really well. Get ready to put in the work though! To receive an A, it is a lot of work, but no more work than putting in a lot of effort into getting an A+ grade on a paper or test for any other class. Nicole is very approachable and cares about her students and their viewpoints. No exams, only assignments.

I would not recommend this course given the new grading system. I missed one journal assignment and my grade went from B to a C+ (It is also hard to keep track whats due), I have straight As so for my other courses so this will hurt. While she is nice, she is inflexible, unwilling to listen, or offer any alternative kind of help or guidance.

The new grading criteria was a mess. Shows absolutely no consideration for students for someone who teaches a social determinants of health class. Random things would bring you two to three grades down. You could work on the assignments with partners but I worked with two other people and it was still a lot of work.

Used a new grading system that overall was iffy. There are a ton of assignments to do (30+) so it's hard to stay organized and takes way too much time. The final grade is more about who has the most time to complete the assignments and not the quality of the work, so those with jobs or lots of courses will do the worst.

the ratings are not reflective of Nicole. She is a very kind hearted prof and tried her best to structure the course to fit COVID-19 and how unpredictable it is. I enjoyed the format of the course very much and the assignments were actually fun to do! great course, and great prof. 10/10

This class is by far one of the best I have taken at SFU. Dr. Berry is very helpful, and very accommodating to the online structure. Instead of exams, you have creative assignments that help you learn new skills. Highly recommend.

I was surprised to see how low her ratings are. Nicole is exceptional at explaining concepts and is very knowledgeable about what she teaches. The course was based on online resources about social issues that are really interesting and eye-opening. Assignments were sometimes a little vague, but overall enjoyable and easy to get full marks.

Really good prof. lectures well and takes time to explain concepts that are a tricky to understand. Exams are easy and fair, as long as you review the lectures and go over article readings you should be fine. Attendance not mandatory, but I would go because they are interesting. overall good experience

Nicole Berry is a decent prof. I think the issues are with her tests and grading criteria. Her tests are marked by two different TAs and the grading criteria is so unclear. The class is curved so only a few people can get an A. The article readings are heavy and confusing her tests are based on these so be prepared. Overall you can survive.

The majority of the lecture notes and lecture will not be examined so don't bother studying it. Just study the readings + reading guides. MC questions are not worded very clearly so make sure you understand EVERYTHING about the readings. Make sure you take notes on the readings too because her lecture notes covering the readings are bare

The group work is straight forward and easy marks. The paper is straight forward too and there's a rubric. However, the multiple exams do not reflect her teaching or the study guides as she suggests. The questions aren't worded well and are not reflective of course material or any work done in lecture. Definitely do NOT recommend this prof.

I don't understand why so many people are complaining, especially since we didn't have a final exam and instead had 3 exams split into parts. Non-cumulative also! As long as you did the study guides, I don't see why you can't get a decent grade. All I did was focus on those guides and got well above average on these exams. Good luck!

The whole course is structured around random academic papers that she selects. Furthermore, she comes to lecture super unorganized and asks students who have read the articles to teach the material to the rest of the other students. Her group assignments are so pointless and are not relevant to the exams.

Avoid her if you can! This class should not be difficult. Her first midterm was brutal and she expects us to know EVERYTHING. The way she constructs questions are weirdly worded and her study guide is hilarious which simply asking a question for every paragraph from the article. Just like highlighting the whole article and stuff them in your brain.
